sub_topic: Finding the cross product of two vectors using trigonometry
message_1: A math student needs to find the cross product of the vectors $\vec{a} = 3\hat{i} + 4\hat{j} - 2\hat{k}$ and $\vec{b} = 2\hat{i} - 5\hat{j} + 6\hat{k}$ using trigonometry. What is the value of $\vec{a} \times \vec{b}$?
message_2:
To find the cross product of two vectors $\vec{a}$ and $\vec{b}$, we can use the following formula:

$\vec{a} \times \vec{b} = \begin{bmatrix} \hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k} \\ a_x & a_y & a_z \\ b_x & b_y & b_z \end{bmatrix}$

where $a_x, a_y, a_z$ are the components of vector $\vec{a}$ and $b_x, b_y, b_z$ are the components of vector $\vec{b}$. 

Now, let's plug in the given values:

$\vec{a} \times \vec{b} = \begin{bmatrix} \hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k} \\ 3 & 4 & -2 \\ 2 & -5 & 6 \end{bmatrix}$

To find the cross product, we can use the cofactor expansion method:

$\vec{a} \times \vec{b} = \hat{i}(4 \cdot 6 - (-2) \cdot (-5)) - \hat{j}(3 \cdot 6 - (-2) \cdot 2) + \hat{k}(3 \cdot (-5) - 4 \cdot 2)$

$\vec{a} \times \vec{b} = \hat{i}(24 - 10) - \hat{j}(18 - 4) + \hat{k}(-15 - 8)$

$\vec{a} \times \vec{b} = 14\hat{i} - 14\hat{j} - 23\hat{k}$

So, the cross product of the given vectors is $\vec{a} \times \vec{b} = 14\hat{i} - 14\hat{j} - 23\hat{k}$.
